Johnson's program, revealed in his inaugural address in January 1965. Some of its better-known programs were Head Start, Medicare, the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Voting Rights Act of 1965. 3. The Executive Order, number 11375, required Federal contractors to take affirmative action to insure that applicants are employed, and treated during employment, without regard to race, color, religion, sex or national origin. It amended Executive Order 11246, from 1965, which did not mention sex in its prohibitions against discrimination in employment. 18. "The Tropic of Cancer" by Grove Press in 1961. 19. results.snippet: ONCE it got off the ground, the Columbia space shuttle mission was a fabulous ride, said Dr. Jeffrey A. Hoffman, one of the seven astronauts aboard. Dr. Hoffman, a 1962 graduate of Scarsdale High School, called the trip a scientific success.   "The...
results.lead_paragraph: ONCE it got off the ground, the Columbia space shuttle mission was a fabulous ride, said Dr. Jeffrey A. Hoffman, one of the seven astronauts aboard. Dr. Hoffman, a 1962 graduate of Scarsdale High School, called the trip a scientific success. "The proof will be in the data we collected," said the astronaut, speaking by telephone recently from his home in Houston. "But the scientists seem to be ecstatic, and that's the important story."

results.snippet: Floating Ice    Q. Why does ice float?    A. Ice floats because water molecules occupy more space in the solid state than in the liquid state, so that a given volume of ice is lighter than the same volume of water, said Bob Park, a spokesman for...
results.lead_paragraph: Floating Ice Q. Why does ice float? A. Ice floats because water molecules occupy more space in the solid state than in the liquid state, so that a given volume of ice is lighter than the same volume of water, said Bob Park, a spokesman for the American Physical Society in Washington and a professor of physics at the University of Maryland in College Park.

headline.main: Astronaut, Quitting NASA, Urges Overhaul of Space Station

results.snippet: An astronaut who is resigning from NASA warned yesterday that its planned $37 billion space station could be canceled outright if its redesign, now under way, was superficial.    Last year the astronaut, Dr. William F. Fisher, led a study that...
results.lead_paragraph: An astronaut who is resigning from NASA warned yesterday that its planned $37 billion space station could be canceled outright if its redesign, now under way, was superficial. Last year the astronaut, Dr. William F. Fisher, led a study that found the 500-foot structure was so complex and fragile that it could need up to 3,700 hours of maintenance a year by space-suited astronauts, as against the designers' original goal of 130 hours.

He said a vote would underline the country's unified resolve. In Kuwait, people are marking off the days on their calendars in anticipation of liberation on Jan. 15. Most Israelis say the huge influx will give the nation new wealth and power, despite a shortage of housing and other problems. American officials said that violence or a crackdown on political activity could endanger relations. The move created a further sense of instability in the Baltic region. The airline, nearly out of cash, will continue to fly and the filing will not affect customers, its chairman said. The airline is the third large American carrier to file in 22 months. The economy of Fort Worth, where General Dynamics would have built the plane, could lose as much as $500 million in trade. headline.main: WAR IN THE GULF: Saudi Arabia; Riyadh Prepares for New Dangers After Iraqi Attack on Israel

results.snippet: The kingdom braced today for growing internal and external threats in the wake of Iraq's missile attacks on Israel and the Saudi city of Dhahran.   The savoring of the coalition's early air successes over Iraq was dramatically cut short in the...

byline.original: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The kingdom braced today for growing internal and external threats in the wake of Iraq's missile attacks on Israel and the Saudi city of Dhahran. The savoring of the coalition's early air successes over Iraq was dramatically cut short in the early hours of the morning by news of the Iraqi attack on Dhahran. The Iraqi missile was intercepted and destroyed by an American-launched Patriot missile, but the attack alarmed Saudis throughout the oil-laden Eastern Province and in the capital.

headline.main: WAR IN THE GULF: The Missing; Despite Downed Jets, Those at Home Retain Hope

results.snippet: The Pentagon had listed Lieut. Robert Wetzel and Lieut. Jeffrey N. Zaun of the Navy and Maj. Thomas F. Koritz of the Air Force as missing in action, their planes lost somewhere over Iraq. But the families and friends of the fliers, two of whom grew...
results.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon had listed Lieut. Robert Wetzel and Lieut. Jeffrey N. Zaun of the Navy and Maj. Thomas F. Koritz of the Air Force as missing in action, their planes lost somewhere over Iraq. But the families and friends of the fliers, two of whom grew up in New Jersey, had not given up hope as they gathered yesterday to pray and remember. "Of course we're hopeful," said Jim Wetzel, one of eight brothers and sisters of Robert, as the family gathered at homes in Neptune City, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., to share their burden. "He's only missing in action, and we're all optimistic."

headline.main: Eastern Airlines Brought Down by a Strike So Bitter It Became a Crusade

results.snippet: As word filtered out Friday night that Eastern Airlines would shut, some members of its machinists union, which has been on strike since March 1989, rejoiced.    Some passengers and communities served by Eastern, as well as other employees,...
results.lead_paragraph: As word filtered out Friday night that Eastern Airlines would shut, some members of its machinists union, which has been on strike since March 1989, rejoiced. Some passengers and communities served by Eastern, as well as other employees, lamented the end of a 62-year-old airline that for a time dominated the routes between the Northeast and the sun, but the strikers celebrated a victory.

results.snippet: WAR IN THE GULF A8-12    The allies intensified their bombing of Iraq as the weather improved. An American plane was shot down, but its pilot was rescued. President Hussein denounced "the forces of arrogance and evil." Page A1    Six Tornado jets...
results.lead_paragraph: WAR IN THE GULF A8-12 The allies intensified their bombing of Iraq as the weather improved. An American plane was shot down, but its pilot was rescued. President Hussein denounced "the forces of arrogance and evil." Page A1 Six Tornado jets have been downed or have crashed so far in the fighting, leaving 10 airmen dead or missing. The British jets fly the most dangerous missions: attacking Iraq's well-defended airfields. A1 Marines "take" Goat Hill, but the camels don't care A9 CBS News crew has vanished near the front lines A9 Iraq barred refugees from leaving, blocking the escape route to Jordan for thousands of foreigners trapped behind the lines and prey to deprivation and bombardment. A1 Basra, Iraq's nerve center, was demolished once before A9 Iraqis are using clouds to cover missile firings A10 Egypt is obliged to liberate Kuwait, President Mubarak said. Facing increasing unease about Egypt's role in the war, he detailed his efforts to resolve the crisis, including 26 appeals to President Hussein. A11 North African nations at the U.N. call for a cease-fire A9 Made homeless by the missiles, 1,000 Israelis fight for aid A10 The move toward European unity has been stalled by the war, which has given new life to the "special relationship" between Britain and the U.S. and raised widespread concern about pacifism in Germany. A11 Will blacks suffer more than whites? Blacks make up 12 percent of the population but account for 25 percent of the troops in the gulf. Many fear they will pay disproportionately; others are proud of their role. A1 News analysis: The cost of the war is uncertain, since no one knows how long it will last or how much the allies will contribute. But the debate in Washington over how to pay for it has already begun. A12 Blissfield Journal: The war brings out hate and hope A14 As a new war rages, opposing voices of the past rise again A14 INTERNATIONAL A2-7 The next U.S.-Soviet summit meeting is very likely to be postponed. President Bush is under pressure from Congress to put off the February meeting in Moscow because of the violence in the Baltic republics. A3 Four Soviet republics defy Gorbachev on currency A3 More pay and freedom for Soviet workers at the United Nations A6 Croatia refused to disarm its police in defiance of mounting threats by Yugoslavia's army. The republic's independence-minded government accused the army of trying to undermine its young democracy. A7 So far from the Mideast: Mongolia's oil intrigues Bush A3 Beijing Journal: What the high walls hide A4 A joint, U.S.-Peru anti-drug program has been drafted by Peru. The plan calls for debt relief and military and development aid. A Peruvian "super ministry" would promote crop substitution and attack traffickers. A2 NATIONAL A14-18 Use of cocaine and crack declined among high school seniors, a study has found. It was the fourth consecutive year that use of cocaine fell and the second and most pronounced decline in crack use. A18 U.S. reports that AIDS Deaths have exceeded 100,000 A18 The deaths of three fans at a concert have stunned Salt Lake City and renewed the controversy over how concertgoers are seated. When AC/DC appeared the crowd surged forward, crushing fans, witnesses said. New York, New Jersey and Connecticut all gained.
